subject: RE: [junit] testing private methods

The way I see the problem of testing private methods is:
for those of you w=
ho would like to see this feature in JUnit, try
developing a nice working s=
olution that fits well into the existing
JUnit codebase.  I'm sure that, if=
 well presented, the JUnit team would
be willing to evaluate your solution =
and add it to a future release (is
this true guys?).

I believe that, if pe=
ople want to test private methods (and this is an
issue that crops up frequ=
ently), they should be allowed to do so (if
such functionality is readilly =
available).

Many people on this list believe that unit testing the public =
API helps
the overall design of the system (low coupling, high cohesion, ..=
.), and
helps decouple solutions from their different implementations.  Man=
y
interesting points and suggestions have been raised over this issue,
howe=
ver, they belong to a Testing&Design discussion, not a Unit Testing
discuss=
ion.

In the light of Unit Testing, if people want to unit test private
met=
hods, so be it.  The JUnit documentation could point out some of the
issues=
 and uses of Unit Tests and how they help with the overall design
of a syst=
em (they may already do so, but its been a while since I last
looked), but =
the tool is for Unit Testing, and as such, should allow
people to use it as=
 they will, so long as they know what they are up to.

Manuel Amago.
